node.title: The 2021 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Winners at Work
node.description: A look at the artists behind this year’s winning books, in their studios.

node.title: Hong Kong’s M+ Museum Is Finally Open. It’s Already in Danger.
node.description: The museum, billed as Asia’s premier art institution, faced construction delays and personnel problems. Now it faces its greatest challenge: the threat of censorship.

node.title: He Stalks Delirious, Unfinished New York as It Rises
node.description: Nick Relph’s new book, “Eclipse Body & Soul Syntax,” collects years of digital street scans of New York City construction posters, an eerie portrait of a supersizing metropolis.

node.title: The 2021 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books
node.description: We invite you to take a look at this year’s winners.

node.title: More Teams Are Contenders This Women’s College Basketball Season
node.description: And some teams at the top have worked hard to get better ahead of the N.C.A.A. tournament in March.

node.title: A Nike Executive Told of Once Killing a Man. Here’s What He Left Out.
node.description: Larry Miller has written a book revealing that at age 16, in 1965, he murdered someone. The disclosure blindsided the family of the victim, whose name he never mentioned.

node.title: The Secret to a Better Internet? Post Less, Chat More.
node.description: One of the web’s oldest functions remains one of its most powerful and promising.

node.title: Madison Saw Something in the Constitution We Should Open Our Eyes To
node.description: The guarantee clause could help Democrats push back against the threat of Republican political hegemony.

node.title: You Are the Object of a Secret Extraction Operation
node.description: Ending data extraction is the key to ending surveillance capitalism.

node.title: It’s Time for the Media to Choose: Neutrality or Democracy?
node.description: Jay Rosen on how the press fundamentally misunderstands American politics.

node.title: Sure, Biden’s Plan Costs a Lot of Money. But the Price of Inaction Is Higher.
node.description: Tell Senator Manchin that failing to deliver is more than we can afford.

node.title: 275 Minutes on Hold: Why Airline Customer Service Still Can’t Keep Up
node.description: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?

node.title: Now TV Wants Nielsen to Measure Up
node.description: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.

node.title: What Bosses Really Think About the Future of the Office
node.description: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.

node.title: Will Zephyr Teachout Finally Have Her Moment?
node.description: The law professor, a darling of New York’s left wing, wants to be attorney general.

node.title: How the Editor of Bon Appétit Spends Her Sundays
node.description: Dawn Davis walks her dog through Central Park and plays tennis to clear her head. And yes, she cooks, too.

node.title: On Rikers Island, a Doctor Who Tends to the Oldest and Sickest
node.description: Insights from Dr. Rachael Bedard, a jail-based geriatrician.

node.title: Saving the Forgotten Connecticut Farm That Helped Spark M.L.K.’s Dream
node.description: Summers spent working on a tobacco farm in the 1940s opened a teenage Martin Luther King Jr. to a world beyond the Jim Crow South.

node.title: Why Open a Bodega When People Will Pay $150 a Pound for Yemeni Coffee?
node.description: Second-generation Yemeni entrepreneurs in Brooklyn want to reclaim their role as the purveyors of the original specialty coffee.

node.title: Why Democrats May Have a Long Wait if They Lose Their Grip on Washington
node.description: Voters’ reflexive instinct to check the party in power makes it hard for any party to retain a hold on both the White House and Congress for long.

node.title: Black Farmworkers Say They Lost Jobs to Foreigners Who Were Paid More
node.description: Longtime field laborers in the Mississippi Delta said in a lawsuit that they were asked to train white guest workers from South Africa before losing their jobs to them.

node.title: Pick-up Artist Tom Torero Sold Sex Recordings, Targeted Teen Girls Using Major Tech Firms
node.description: Leaked footage obtained by Newsweek suggests pick-up artist Tom Torero had secretly recorded audio of himself having sex with women and sold the content.

node.title: Black Lives Matter Co-Founder Says Democrats Have 'Dragged Their Feet' on Racial Justice
node.description: BLM's Ayọ Tometi said the movement needed more power and that it had not enjoyed the kind of access to the White House people have assumed.

node.title: Out of 1.1 Million Homeland Security Threat Reports, Only 1,200 Used the Word 'Trump'
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: U.K. woman demands change after "strange" spiking at nightclub
node.description: In the last two months, police in the U.K. have received at least 56 reports of people fearing they've been stuck by needles in drugging attempts, and boycotts of clubs have taken place in cities across the country.

node.title: Beloved dolphin Winter, of "Dolphin Tale" movies, has died at 16
node.description: The prosthetic-tailed dolphin's real-life story of rehabilitation became an inspiration for disabled people around the world. It died of intestinal issues.

node.title: Aussies highlight positives from poor T20 World Cup build-up after reaching final
node.description: Australia lost five consecutive T20 series prior to the men's World Cup, but coach Justin Langer believes the experience ultimately benefited his squad.

node.title: This funnel-web spider could bite through your fingernail. Its venom will also save lives
node.description: A massive funnel-web spider with fangs so long they could bite through a human fingernail is donated to a lifesaving antivenom program at the Australian Reptile Park.

node.title: Who's on the International Space Station? Video Shows Astronauts Entering After Dragon Docks
node.description: With seven people on board, the ISS is now back to its standard capacity following a crew switchover.

node.title: Tributes Paid to Winter the Dolphin, Star of 'Dolphin Tale,' Dead at 16
node.description: The marine mammal became an inspiration when she was equipped with a prosthetic tail in 2005 after she was caught in a crab trap and it left her unable to swim.

node.title: Child rescued from alleged porn operation, as man faces 43 charges
node.description: A child has been rescued, and a man from the Sunshine Coast has been charged with more than 40 child abuse offences, including rape, after a five-day police operation.

node.title: In Ocasio-Cortez’s District, Disagreements About the Democrats’ Direction
node.description: She voted against the infrastructure bill. Now, even in her own district, she faces questions of whether she put her constituents’ interests first.

node.title: In-N-Out Burger Rejects Ron DeSantis Pitch to Move to Florida
node.description: The fast food chain got the offer after its San Francisco outlet was closed for refusing to adhere to vaccination proof rules.

node.title: Court hears alleged murder victim's house was unusually clean and smelt like bleach
node.description: The trial of Paul Winston Oatey continues in Adelaide's Supreme Court. He is accused of murdering 53-year-old Darren Perry in December 2019. The teenage girl who the court heard discovered Mr Perry's body in a backyard gives evidence.

node.title: Katherine mask mandate extended after positive COVID-19 wastewater results
node.description: A mask mandate in the town of Katherine is extended for a further 24 hours after positive wastewater results were detected in the region.

node.title: 'Not the smartest thing': Black Caps star breaks hand punching bat, ruled out of T20 World Cup final
node.description: An outburst of frustration leaves Devon Conway nursing a broken hand following New Zealand's semi-final victory over England, ruling the wicketkeeper-batter out of the tournament decider against Australia.

node.title: Shearing on at A and P show with no crowd
node.description: An oink here, a baa baa there, that's the Canty show this year as some competitiors take to the grounds with no spectators due to Covid-19.

node.title: Ocasio-Cortez Isn’t Wavering. Are New Yorkers on Her Side?
node.description: By voting no on the infrastructure bill, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez set off a fierce debate, including among city residents eager to see the subways improved.

node.title: Graeme Edge, co-founder of The Moody Blues, dies at 80
node.description: Moody Blues frontman Justin Hayward confirms Graeme Edge's death on the group's website. The cause of his death has not been revealed.

node.title: 'Daigou is dying', but Australian products remain popular in China despite trade tensions
node.description: The world's largest online shopping festival sets a new sales record, with Australian products playing a big part, but year-on-year growth falls to its slowest since the event began.

node.title: Prison Won’t Be a Riot for the QAnon Shaman, Jimmy Kimmel Says
node.description: “Prosecutors are recommending 51 months behind bars, after which, he will be remanded into the custody of ‘Dancing With the Stars,’” Kimmel joked.

node.title: Manfred achieves his dream of becoming a physicist — at age 89
node.description: Manfred Steiner, 89, decided to study physics rather than hit around golf balls after retirement — earning his PhD and inspiring others to pursue their ambitions at any age.

node.title: Migration and Experimentation: What Led to Australia’s Coffee Culture
node.description: When Italian migrants arrived after World War II, they helped develop a coffee scene that many now regard as the best in the world.

node.title: American journalist jailed for 11 years in Myanmar
node.description: A court in military-ruled Myanmar sentences US journalist Danny Fenster to 11 years in jail, as he still faces several more serious charges including terrorism.

node.title: The net zero modelling's been released. Here are some of the big assumptions
node.description: To save you spending your Friday night sifting through the government's modelling for its net zero by 2050 plan, here are a few of the key takeaways.

node.title: Flood fallout: Residents still stranded in 'beautiful prison'
node.description: Four months after one of Marlborough's worst storms cut their road access, residents of Kenepuru Sound are still relying on boats for their supplies and livelihoods.

node.title: Police and Customs seize $8 million worth of drugs
node.description: Police seized 17kg of methamphetamine, 5.44kg of MDMA and 1kg of pseudoephedrine after a six-month investigation in Northland.

node.title: Invercargill mayor Sir Tim Shadbolt still storing personal items in council-owned buildings
node.description: Invercargill mayor Sir Tim Shadbolt is still using council-owned buildings for personal storage, three months after he made headlines over the unorthodox arrangement.

node.title: Myanmar court sentences U.S. journalist Danny Fenster to 11 years
node.description: He was convicted of charges including incitement and faces other charges that could bring a life sentence. Fenster is the only foreign journalist convicted of a serious crime since a military coup in May.

node.title: Myanmar Court Sentences American Journalist to 11 Years
node.description: Danny Fenster, who was arrested in May by the military government, was given the maximum sentence on Friday after being convicted on three charges, his employer said.
